app

Class EmptySea

  • java.lang.Object
    • app.Ship
      • app.EmptySea

  • public class EmptySea
extends Ship

    Subclass of class Ship. Represents a place in the ocean in which there is no Ship.

    It is a part of the Battleship game application, which is run by the class BattleshipGame.

    The length of this "Ship" is 1, it returns false when shot at and when inquired if it is sunk, and its toString method returns "-" if it has been shot at and "." if it hasn't.

    Since:
    17th December 2014
    Version:
    1.0
    Author:
    Liran Harary (lharar01, 12837230)

      This method overrides Ship's shootAt method, and always returns false to indicate that nothing was hit, as this is location contains empty sea.

    • Constructor Detail

      • EmptySea

        public EmptySea()

        Sets the length to 1.

        Sets all elements in the hit array to false.

    • Method Detail

      • shootAt

        public boolean shootAt(int row,
                       int column)

        This method overrides Ship's shootAt method, and always returns false to indicate that nothing was hit, as this is location contains empty sea.

        Additionally it marks hit[0] as true, to indicate that this location has been shot at.

        Overrides:
        shootAt in class Ship
        Parameters:
        row - shot row.
        column - shot column.
        Returns:
        false

      • isSunk

        public boolean isSunk()
        This method overrides Ship's isSunk method, and always returns false to indicate that no (real) Ships have been sunk.
        Overrides:
        isSunk in class Ship
        Returns:
        false

      • toString

        public java.lang.String toString()

        Returns "-" if this Ship has been fired upon, and "." if it has not.

        This symbol is then used in the Ocean's print method to denote the state of the Ship.

        Overrides:
        toString in class Ship
        Returns:
        hit[0]
